questions.text: Patient is having visual disturbance. On examination a vessel developed an aneurysm at the base of the brain, compressing optic chiasm, which of the following is involved
questions.solution:
The below image shows the blood supply of optic chiasma of which anterior communicating artery is on of its supply.

  • As per shown in both the figure the anterior communicating artery is in close contact of optic chiasma.
  • So an aneurysm of it can compress the optic chiasm, leading to visual disturbance.

questions.text: A 34 years old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation , the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structure prevent vertical and downward descent of the spleen ?
questions.solution:
• The phrenicocolic ligament is not attached to the spleen, but supports its anterior end. It is a horizontal fold of peritoneum extending from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, opposite the 11th rib in the midaxillary line.
  • It limits the upper end of the left paracolic gutter.
  • It is preventing downwards displacement so It is also called sustentaculum lienis.

questions.text: Identify the type of papillae shown in the microscopic picture of tongue given
questions.solution:
the papillae of tongue are:

  1. Circumvallate papillae
  2. Foliate papillae
  3. Fungiform papillae
  4. Filiform papillae
  • The histological image in the question is of circumvallate papillae
  • Circumvallate papillae are characterized by their dome-shaped structure lined by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Numerous oval shaped lightly stained taste buds can be seen on the lateral wall of the papillae.
  • The underlying connective tissue contains serous glands of Von Ebner.
  • Skeletal muscle can be seen extending into the papillae.

Key -

  1. Groove around papilla
  2. Taste bud
  3. Serous glands of Von Ebner
  4. Muscle extending into papilla

questions.text: A patient with multiple humeral fractures, severe weakness in flexion and supination of forearm and loss of sensation in lateral side of forearm. Which nerve is commonly injured?
questions.solution:
• Muscular branches: It supplies the following muscles of the front of the arm.
    • Coracobrachialis
    • Biceps brachii, long and short heads
    • Brachialis
  • Cutaneous branches: Through the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, it supplies the skin of the lateral side of the forearm from the elbow to the wrist including the ball of the thumb
  • Injury to Musculocutaneous nerve:
    • Loss or weakness of flexion due to paralysis of brachialis muscle
    • Weakness of supination due to paralysis of biceps brachii muscle
    • Loss of sensation skin of the lateral side of the forearm

questions.text: Patient was presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting malignancy ,submandibular gland was resected.. Which of the most likely nerves to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?
questions.solution:
• Submandibular duct:
  • It is thin walled, and is about 5 cm long.
  • It emerges at the anterior end of the deep part of the gland and runs upwards and forwards on the hyoglossus, between the lingual and hypoglossal nerves.
  • At the anterior border of the hyoglossus, the duct is crossed by the lingual nerve. This is commonly injured during removal of duct.
  • It opens on the floor of the mouth, on the summit of the sublingual papilla, at the side of the frenulum of the tongue.

questions.text: A patient underwent coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complaint of paraesthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
• The great or long saphenous vein is formed by the union of the medial end of dorsal venous arch with the medial marginal vein which drains the medial side of the great
  • It passes upwards in front of the medial malleolus, crosses the lower one-third of the medial surface of the tibia obliquely, and runs along its medial border to reach the back of the knee.
  • The saphenous nerve runs in front of the great saphenous vein.
  • The saphenous nerve is a branch of the posterior division of the femoral nerve
  • It supplies the skin of the medial side of the leg and the medial border of the foot up to the ball of the great toe.

- Cutaneous nerves on front of the leg and dorsum of foot is as follow :

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure ?
questions.solution:
- Gag reflex:It is a protective reflex characterized by the elevation of the palate and contraction of pharyngeal muscles with associated retching and gagging in response to stimulation of the mucus membrane of the Oropharynx.

- It occurs when the palate, tonsil, posterior part of tongue or posterior pharyngeal wall are touched by unfamiliar objects such as swab and spatula.

- The afferent limb of the reflex is provided by the Glossopharyngeal nerve and the efferent limb by the vagus nerve.

questions.text: This test is for which nerve
questions.solution:
• Pen/pencil test for abductor pollicis brevis:
  • Lay the hand flat on a table with the palm directed upwards.
  • The patient is unable to touch with his thumb a pen/ pencil held in front of the palm
  • The abductor pollicis brevis is thenar group of muscle. It is supplied by Median Nerve.

MEDIAN NERVE INJURY SIGNS
